original_theorem:
A point $\overline{x}$ is a limit
point of a set $S$ if and only if there is a sequence $\{x_n\}$ of points
in $S$ such that $x_n\ne\overline{x}$ for $n\ge 1,$ and
$$
\lim_{n\to\infty}x_n=\overline{x}.
$$
theorem_translation:
```lean4
theorem is_limit_point_iff_exists_ne_sub_sequence {Î± : Type*} [MetricSpace Î±] {S : Set Î±} {x_bar : Î±} :
    x_bar âˆˆ closure (S \ {x_bar}) â†” âˆƒ (x : â„• â†’ Î±), (âˆ€ n, x n âˆˆ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ n, x n â‰  x_bar) âˆ§ (Tendsto x atTop (nhds x_bar)) := by
```

theorem is_limit_point_iff_exists_ne_sub_sequence {Î± : Type*} [MetricSpace Î±] {S : Set Î±} {x_bar : Î±} :
    x_bar âˆˆ closure (S \ {x_bar}) â†” âˆƒ (x : â„• â†’ Î±), (âˆ€ n, x n âˆˆ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ n, x n â‰  x_bar) âˆ§ (Tendsto x atTop (nhds x_bar)) := by sorry

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
â€¢ There is a sequence $\{x_n\}_{n\geq 1}$ of points in a set $S$ such that $x_n
e\overline{x}$ for all $n\ge 1,$ and $\lim_{n\to\infty}x_n=\overline{x}$ [tc_1].
Therefore, we conclude:
â€¢ For each $\epsilon>0$, there exists an integer $N$ such that for all $n\ge N$, we have $0<|x_n-\overline{x}|<\epsilon$ [l1].

    x_bar âˆˆ closure (S \ {x_bar}) â†” âˆƒ (x : â„• â†’ Î±), (âˆ€ n, x n âˆˆ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ n, x n â‰  x_bar) âˆ§ (Tendsto x atTop (nhds x_bar)) := by

    x_bar âˆˆ closure (S \ {x_bar}) â†” âˆƒ (x : â„• â†’ Î±), (âˆ€ n, x n âˆˆ S) âˆ§ (âˆ€ n, x n â‰  x_bar) âˆ§ (Tendsto x atTop (nhds x_bar)) := by
  constructor

proof_steps.natural_language:
We assume:
â€¢ The sequence $\{x_n\}$ is in the set $S$ [tc_1].

â€¢ Every $\epsilon$-neighborhood of $\overline{x}$ (the set of points $y$ with $|y - \overline{x}| < \epsilon$) contains infinitely many points of $S$ [l2].
